Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: The phone in my hand felt heavier than usual as I glanced at the clock—just two hours left before the polls closed. My manager’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding us that missing the sales target today meant no bonuses, maybe even penalties. I dialed another number, rehearsing my pitch, but my thoughts kept drifting to the polling station across town. I’d promised myself I’d vote this year, convinced that my voice mattered. But every call I made was another minute lost, another chance to close a sale and help the team. My inbox pinged with urgent reminders from both the company and the election commission. I could almost feel the weight of both expectations pressing down on me: the responsibility to my job, my team, my own paycheck, and the responsibility to my community, my country. My heart pounded as I stared at the list of leads and the clock ticking down, torn between dialing the next number and grabbing my coat to rush out the door.
